article:
Kang Full
================

Kang Full is a renowned South Korean cartoonist, known for his eclectic and imaginative storytelling style, which has captivated audiences worldwide. With a career spanning over three decades, Kang Full has established himself as one of the most influential and innovative creators in the world of webtoons and manhwa.

Early Life and Education
------------------------

Kang Full was born on January 12, 1970, in Seoul, South Korea. Growing up in a family of modest means, Kang Full developed a passion for drawing and storytelling at an early age. He spent most of his childhood reading comics and manhwa, which would later inspire his own creative style. Kang Full attended Hongik University, where he studied fine arts and honed his craft as a cartoonist.

Career
-------

### Early Career

Kang Full began his career in the early 1990s, working as an assistant to several established cartoonists. During this period, he refined his skills and developed his unique style, which blended elements of humor, satire, and social commentary. In 1993, Kang Full published his first solo work, a webtoon titled "The Ordinary," which gained moderate success and laid the groundwork for his future projects.

### Career Breakthrough

Kang Full's breakthrough came in 1999 with the publication of "Apartment," a serialized webtoon that explored the lives of young adults living in a Seoul apartment complex. The series was a massive hit, attracting millions of readers and establishing Kang Full as a major talent in the world of webtoons.

### Serialized Fiction Webtoons

Throughout the 2000s, Kang Full continued to push the boundaries of webtoon storytelling with serialized fiction series like "Freeze," "Carnivore," and "Wet Moon." These works showcased his ability to craft complex, engaging narratives that captivated readers worldwide.

### Kang's Action Series: Moving, Bridge, and Hidden

In the mid-2000s, Kang Full turned his attention to action-oriented webtoons with the publication of "Moving," "Bridge," and "Hidden." These series demonstrated his mastery of pacing, suspense, and visual storytelling, cementing his reputation as a versatile and innovative creator.

Other Work
------------

### Children Picture Books

In addition to his webtoon work, Kang Full has also created several children's picture books, including "The Little Rabbit" and "The Magic Paintbrush." These works showcase his ability to craft engaging, imaginative stories for younger readers.

### The Kang Full Cartoon Alley

In 2015, Kang Full opened the Kang Full Cartoon Alley, a museum and exhibition space dedicated to the art of webtoons and manhwa. The alley features exhibits on Kang Full's work, as well as other prominent cartoonists and illustrators.

Working Style
--------------

### Art Style/Technique and Materials

Kang Full's art style is characterized by its eclecticism and versatility. He has experimented with a wide range of techniques and materials, from traditional ink and watercolor to digital drawing and painting. His use of bold lines, vibrant colors, and expressive characters has become a hallmark of his work.

### Kang Full Universe

Kang Full's webtoons and manhwa are often set within a shared universe, where characters and storylines intersect and overlap. This approach has created a rich, immersive world that rewards close reading and attention.

Personal Life
--------------

Kang Full is known for his reclusive nature and rarely gives interviews or makes public appearances. Despite this, he has built a devoted following among fans and fellow creators, who admire his dedication to his craft and his willingness to push the boundaries of webtoon storytelling.

Government and Intergovernmental Reactions to the Russian Invasion of Ukraine

The Russian invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24, 2022, has sparked widespread condemnation and reactions from governments and intergovernmental organizations around the world. The international community has been divided in their responses, with some countries strongly condemning Russia's actions, while others have taken a more neutral or supportive stance.

# Ukraine

Ukraine has been at the forefront of the crisis, with its government and people bearing the brunt of the Russian invasion. The Ukrainian government has appealed to the international community for support, calling for economic sanctions against Russia and military aid to help defend its territory. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has been a vocal advocate for his country's interests, engaging in diplomatic efforts to rally support from world leaders.

# Russia

Russia has justified its invasion of Ukraine as a necessary measure to protect its own security interests and the rights of Russian-speaking populations in Ukraine. The Russian government has rejected international criticism, accusing Western countries of hypocrisy and double standards. Russian President Vladimir Putin has maintained that Russia's actions are aimed at "denazifying" Ukraine and preventing the country from joining NATO.

* United States: The US has been a vocal critic of Russia's actions, imposing economic sanctions and providing military aid to Ukraine.
* United Kingdom: The UK has also condemned Russia's invasion, imposing sanctions and providing diplomatic support to Ukraine.

* Australia: Australia has condemned Russia's invasion, imposing sanctions and providing diplomatic support to Ukraine.

NATO has taken a strong stance against Russia's invasion of Ukraine, calling it a violation of international law and a threat to global security. NATO has provided military aid to Ukraine and has increased its military presence in Eastern Europe.

## European Union

The European Union has also taken a strong stance against Russia's invasion of Ukraine, imposing economic sanctions and providing humanitarian aid to Ukraine.

## International Criminal Court

The International Criminal Court has launched an investigation into war crimes committed during the conflict, including allegations of Russian war crimes in Ukraine.

article:
2021–2023 ICC World Test Championship

The 2021–2023 ICC World Test Championship was the second edition of the ICC World Test Championship, a biennial Test cricket tournament organized by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The championship was contested by the top nine Test teams in the world, with the teams playing each other in a series of Test matches over a period of two years.

Format
--------

The championship was played in a league format, with each team playing six series, three at home and three away, against the other eight teams. Each series consisted of two to five Test matches, with the teams earning points based on the outcome of each match. The team with the most points at the end of the league stage qualified for the final, where they played against the second-placed team to determine the champion.

Points system
-------------

The points system for the championship was as follows:

* A win: 12 points
* A draw: 4 points
* A tie: 6 points
* A loss: 0 points

In addition to these points, teams were also awarded bonus points for winning matches by a significant margin. A team that won a match by an innings or by 10 wickets or more earned 4 bonus points, while a team that won a match by 7-9 wickets or by 150 runs or more earned 2 bonus points.

Participants
------------

The following nine teams participated in the championship:

*  Australia
*  Bangladesh
*  England
*  India
*  New Zealand
*  Pakistan
*  South Africa
*  Sri Lanka
*  West Indies

Broadcasters
------------

The championship was broadcast live in various countries around the world. The broadcasting rights for the championship were held by the following networks:

*  Australia: Fox Sports
*  Bangladesh: T Sports
*  England: Sky Sports
*  India: Star Sports
*  New Zealand: Sky Sport
*  Pakistan: PTV Sports
*  South Africa: SuperSport
*  Sri Lanka: Dialog TV
*  West Indies: ESPN

Schedule
--------

The championship began on August 4, 2021, and concluded on March 31, 2023. The schedule for the championship was as follows:

* August 4-8, 2021: England v India (Pataudi Trophy)

The total prize money for the championship was $3.8 million, with the winning team receiving $1.6 million and the runner-up team receiving $800,000.

article:
Ranil Wickremesinghe

Ranil Wickremesinghe is a Sri Lankan politician who has served as the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka six times and as the President of Sri Lanka from 2022 to 2024. He is the leader of the United National Party (UNP) and has been a key figure in Sri Lankan politics for over four decades. Wickremesinghe has been a strong advocate for democracy, human rights, and economic development, and has played a crucial role in shaping the country's foreign policy and economic reforms.

#Early life and education

Ranil Wickremesinghe was born on March 24, 1949, in Colombo, Sri Lanka, to Esmond Wickremesinghe and Nalini Wickremesinghe. His father was a lawyer and a politician who served as the Minister of Justice in the 1950s. Wickremesinghe received his primary education at the Royal College, Colombo, and later attended the University of Ceylon, where he earned a degree in law. He was called to the bar in 1972 and began his career as a lawyer.

#Political career

Wickremesinghe's entry into politics was marked by his appointment as the Minister of Youth Affairs and Employment in 1977, at the age of 28. He quickly rose through the ranks of the UNP and became a key ally of President J.R. Jayewardene.

##Batalanda incident

In the late 1980s, Wickremesinghe was embroiled in the Batalanda incident, a controversy surrounding the alleged torture and disappearance of several individuals at a detention center in Batalanda. Wickremesinghe, who was then the Minister of Industries, was accused of being involved in the cover-up, but he denied any wrongdoing.

##First premiership (1993–1994)

Wickremesinghe first became Prime Minister in 1993, following the assassination of President Ranasinghe Premadasa. His tenure was marked by efforts to revitalize the economy and promote peace talks with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE).

##Opposition (1994–2001)

Wickremesinghe's UNP lost the 1994 parliamentary elections, and he became the Leader of the Opposition. During this period, he focused on rebuilding the party and promoting democratic values.

###1999 presidential election

In the 1999 presidential election, Wickremesinghe ran as the UNP candidate, but lost to Chandrika Kumaratunga of the People's Alliance.

##Second premiership (2001–2004)

Wickremesinghe returned as Prime Minister in 2001, following the UNP's victory in the parliamentary elections. His second tenure was marked by efforts to promote peace talks with the LTTE and implement economic reforms.

###Peace talks

Wickremesinghe played a key role in initiating peace talks with the LTTE, which led to the signing of a ceasefire agreement in 2002. However, the talks ultimately broke down, and the conflict resumed.

##Opposition (2004–2015)

Wickremesinghe's UNP lost the 2004 parliamentary elections, and he became the Leader of the Opposition once again. During this period, he focused on promoting democratic values and opposing the authoritarian tendencies of the Mahinda Rajapaksa government.

###2005 presidential election

In the 2005 presidential election, Wickremesinghe ran as the UNP candidate, but lost to Mahinda Rajapaksa of the United People's Freedom Alliance.

###Dissent within the UNP

Wickremesinghe faced challenges from within his own party, as some members called for his resignation as leader. However, he managed to maintain his position and continue to lead the party.

###End of the civil war and 2010 presidential election

The civil war ended in 2009, with the defeat of the LTTE. In the 2010 presidential election, Wickremesinghe ran as the UNP candidate, but lost to Mahinda Rajapaksa.

##Third, fourth and fifth premierships (2015–2019)

Wickremesinghe returned as Prime Minister in 2015, following the UNP's victory in the parliamentary elections. He served as Prime Minister for a third, fourth, and fifth time, until the 2019 presidential election.

###Foreign policy

During his third tenure as Prime Minister, Wickremesinghe played a key role in promoting Sri Lanka's foreign policy and strengthening ties with other countries, particularly in the region.

###Government bonds controversy

Wickremesinghe was embroiled in a controversy surrounding the issuance of government bonds, which led to allegations of corruption and mismanagement.

##Opposition (2019–2022)

Wickremesinghe's UNP lost the 2019 presidential election, and he became the Leader of the Opposition once again.

##Sixth premiership (2022)

Wickremesinghe was appointed as Prime Minister for a sixth time in 2022, following the resignation of Mahinda Rajapaksa amid a severe economic crisis.

#Presidency (2022–2024)

Wickremesinghe was elected as President of Sri Lanka in 2022, following the resignation of Gotabaya Rajapaksa.

##Crackdown on anti-government protests

Wickremesinghe faced criticism for his government's crackdown on anti-government protests, which led to allegations of human rights abuses.

##Handling of economic crisis

Wickremesinghe's government implemented austerity measures to address the economic crisis, but faced criticism for the impact on the poor and vulnerable.

##2023 local government elections

Wickremesinghe's government faced a setback in the 2023 local government elections, which saw significant gains for opposition parties.

##2024 presidential election

Wickremesinghe lost the 2024 presidential election to a candidate from the opposition, marking the end of his presidency.

#Family and personal life

Wickremesinghe is married to Maitree Wickremesinghe, a lawyer and women's rights activist. He has no children.

#Honours

Wickremesinghe has received several honors and awards for his contributions to democracy and human rights.

article:
Killing of Jayland Walker

On June 27, 2022, Jayland Walker, a 25-year-old African American man, was shot and killed by police officers in Akron, Ohio, United States. The incident sparked widespread outrage and protests, with many calling for justice and accountability for the officers involved.

# Background

Jayland Walker was born on December 16, 1996, in Akron, Ohio. He grew up in the city and attended Buchtel High School. After high school, Walker worked as a food delivery driver and was engaged to be married. According to his family and friends, Walker was a kind and gentle person who loved his community and was committed to making a positive impact.

The Akron Police Department (APD) had a history of tensions with the local community, particularly with African American residents. In 2020, the APD was sued by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) for allegedly engaging in racial profiling and using excessive force against Black people. The lawsuit was settled in 2022, with the APD agreeing to implement reforms and increase transparency.

# Incident

On June 27, 2022, at around 12:30 a.m., APD officers attempted to stop Walker's car for a minor traffic violation. Walker, who was driving alone, fled the scene, leading the officers on a high-speed chase through the city. The chase ended when Walker's car crashed into a police cruiser in a parking lot.

According to the APD, Walker exited the vehicle and began to flee on foot. Officers claimed that Walker made a sudden movement and reached for his waistband, prompting them to open fire. Walker was shot at least 60 times and died at the scene.

# Investigation

The Ohio Bureau of Investigation (BBI) was called in to investigate the shooting. The BBI collected evidence from the scene, including body camera footage from the officers involved. The footage was later released to the public, sparking widespread outrage and calls for justice.

article:
Boys Planet

Boys Planet is a 2023 South Korean reality competition television series created by Mnet. The show premiered on February 2, 2023, and concluded on April 20, 2023. The program aimed to create a new boy group through a competition among 98 contestants from various entertainment agencies and independent trainees.

# Concept and format

Boys Planet adopted a unique format, where contestants were divided into two groups: "Group A" and "Group X". Group A consisted of trainees from well-known entertainment agencies, while Group X comprised trainees from smaller agencies and independent trainees. The competition was designed to test the contestants' singing, rapping, dancing, and other skills.

## Voting system

The voting system played a crucial role in determining the contestants' rankings. Viewers could vote for their favorite contestants through the Mnet Plus app, and the top contestants with the most votes would receive benefits such as advantages in the competition and priority in choosing their team members.

# Promotion and broadcast

Boys Planet was heavily promoted through various social media platforms, including YouTube, TikTok, and Instagram. The show's official accounts shared behind-the-scenes content, contestant profiles, and episode previews to generate buzz and excitement among fans.

## Broadcast schedule

Boys Planet aired every Thursday on Mnet at 8:00 PM KST, with each episode approximately 120 minutes long. The show was also available to stream on various online platforms, including Mnet's official website and YouTube channel.

# Cast

The show featured a lineup of experienced hosts, trainers, and judges who guided the contestants throughout the competition.

* Sunmi: Host
* Hwang Min-hyun: Host
* Jo Gyu-min: Vocal trainer
* Shim Jae-won: Vocal trainer
* Lee Joo-young: Dance trainer
* Jo A-young: Rap trainer
* Bang Si-hyuk: Judge
* Jang Won-young: Judge

# Contestants

A total of 98 contestants participated in Boys Planet, representing various entertainment agencies and independent trainees. Some notable contestants include:

* Sung Han-bin (Hanbin)
* Lee Hyeop
* Lee Seung-hoon
* Kim Gyu-vin
* Kim Tae-rae
* Park Gun-wook

# Ranking

The contestants' rankings were determined by the voting system and their performance in each episode.

## Top 9

The top 9 contestants with the most votes were announced at the end of each episode and received benefits such as advantages in the competition and priority in choosing their team members.

## First voting period

The first voting period took place from February 2 to 9, and the top 9 contestants were announced at the end of episode 2.

## Second voting period

The second voting period took place from February 16 to 23, and the top 9 contestants were announced at the end of episode 4.

## Third voting period

The third voting period took place from March 2 to 9, and the top 9 contestants were announced at the end of episode 6.

## Result

The final ranking was announced at the end of the last episode, and the top contestants formed a new boy group.

# Episodes

Boys Planet consisted of 12 episodes, each with a unique theme and challenge.

1. Episode 1: "Introduction"
2. Episode 2: "Group A vs. Group X"
3. Episode 3: "Rival Match"
4. Episode 4: "Team Battle"
5. Episode 5: "Position Evaluation"
6. Episode 6: "Concept Evaluation"
7. Episode 7: "Mentor's Match"
8. Episode 8: "Debut Evaluation"
9. Episode 9: "Semifinal"
10. Episode 10: "Final"
11. Episode 11: "Special Episode"
12. Episode 12: "Final Result"

# Discography

Boys Planet released several singles and extended plays throughout the competition.

## Extended plays

1. "Here I Am"
2. "Get Back"

## Singles

1. "Blaze"
2. "Switch"
3. "Beautiful"

# Viewership

Boys Planet received significant viewership throughout its run, with its peak episode reaching over 2 million viewers.

# Awards and nominations

Boys Planet won several awards, including the Best Variety Show award at the 2023 Mnet Asian Music Awards.

# Aftermath

The winner of Boys Planet, Zero Base One, debuted on July 10, 2023, with their single "Blaze".

# Notes

Boys Planet was a groundbreaking show that brought together contestants from different backgrounds and entertainment agencies. The show's unique format and voting system made it a hit among fans, and its impact on the K-pop industry was significant.

# References

(N/A)

* Official website

* Instagram account

article:
2023 The Hundred Season

The 2023 season of The Hundred was the third edition of the Hundred, an English cricket tournament launched by the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB). The tournament featured eight teams, with both men's and women's divisions. The competition ran from August 1 to August 27, 2023.

# Teams

The eight teams that participated in the 2023 season of The Hundred were:

* Birmingham Phoenix
* London Spirit
* Manchester Originals
* Northern Superchargers
* Oval Invincibles
* Southern Brave
* Trent Rockets
* Welsh Fire

# Tournament structure

The tournament followed a round-robin group stage format, with each team playing seven matches against the other teams in their division. The top three teams in both the men's and women's divisions qualified for the knockout stages.

# Squads

## Women

Each team had a squad of 15 players for the women's division, with a mix of England internationals, domestic players, and overseas players. Some notable players in the women's division included:

* Birmingham Phoenix: Amy Jones, Ellyse Perry
* London Spirit: Beth Mooney, Deandra Dottin
* Manchester Originals: Sophie Ecclestone, Lizelle Lee
* Northern Superchargers: Hollie Armitage, Alyssa Healy
* Oval Invincibles: Lauren Winfield-Hill, Marizanne Kapp
* Southern Brave: Danni Wyatt, Smriti Mandhana
* Trent Rockets: Katherine Brunt, Natalie Sciver
* Welsh Fire: Hayley Matthews, Tammy Beaumont

## Men

Each team had a squad of 15 players for the men's division, with a mix of England internationals, domestic players, and overseas players. Some notable players in the men's division included:

* Birmingham Phoenix: Liam Livingstone, Moeen Ali
* London Spirit: Eoin Morgan, Glenn Maxwell
* Manchester Originals: Jos Buttler, Lockie Ferguson
* Northern Superchargers: Adil Rashid, David Willey
* Oval Invincibles: Will Jacks, Sunil Narine
* Southern Brave: Jofra Archer, Quinton de Kock
* Trent Rockets: Dawid Malan, Rashid Khan
* Welsh Fire: Jonny Bairstow, Ollie Pope

## Replacements

Teams were allowed to make replacements for injured players or those who were unavailable due to international commitments. Some notable replacements included:

* Birmingham Phoenix: Chris Woakes (replaced Liam Livingstone)
* London Spirit: Zak Crawley (replaced Eoin Morgan)
* Manchester Originals: Matt Parkinson (replaced Jos Buttler)

# Format

The Hundred featured a unique format, with each match lasting 100 balls per team. The matches were divided into innings, with each team facing 100 balls. The team with the higher score at the end of the 100 balls won the match.

# Broadcasting

The 2023 season of The Hundred was broadcast on Sky Sports and the BBC. Sky Sports showed all 64 matches, while the BBC showed 10 matches, including the final.

Lahaina, Hawaii

Lahaina is a historic town located on the west coast of the island of Maui, Hawaii, United States. It is the largest census-designated place in West Maui and the second-largest town in Maui County. Lahaina has a rich cultural heritage and was once the capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii. Today, it is a popular tourist destination known for its historic sites, beautiful beaches, and vibrant arts and culture scene.

# History

## Name

### Modern name, etymology and pronunciations

The modern name "Lahaina" is derived from the Hawaiian words "la" meaning "day" and "haina" meaning "cruel" or "relentless". The name is often translated as "cruel sun" or "relentless sun". In ancient times, the town was known for its sunny weather, and the name likely refers to the intense heat of the sun. The pronunciation of Lahaina is often anglicized as "lah-HY-nah", but the traditional Hawaiian pronunciation is more like "lah-HEE-nah".

### Ancient names

Before the arrival of Westerners, the town was known by several ancient names, including "Lele", "Lahaina i ka uaua" (Lahaina in the heat), and "Mokuula" (the island). The name "Lahaina" became widely used in the 19th century, and it has been the official name of the town since then.

## Early rulers

Lahaina was an important center of power and politics in ancient Hawaii. The town was ruled by a series of ali'i (chiefs) who were believed to have divine authority. One of the most famous early rulers of Lahaina was Pi'ilani, a 14th-century chief who united the island of Maui under one rule. Pi'ilani built several temples and fishponds in the Lahaina area, including the famous Mokuula temple, which was believed to be the dwelling place of the gods.

## Western contact

### Kahekili II

In 1786, Lahaina was visited by the British explorer George Vancouver, who was the first European to set foot on Maui. Vancouver was greeted by the ruler of Lahaina, Kahekili II, who was a powerful and intelligent chief. Kahekili II was interested in establishing trade relations with the British and offered Vancouver food, shelter, and other gifts.

### Kamehameha I and Kamehameha II

In the late 18th century, Lahaina was conquered by Kamehameha I, the founder of the Kingdom of Hawaii. Kamehameha I established Lahaina as his temporary capital and built several temples, including the famous Luakini temple. After Kamehameha I's death, his son Kamehameha II continued to rule from Lahaina and introduced Western customs and laws to the kingdom.

### Christian missionaries

In 1820, the first Christian missionaries arrived in Lahaina, led by the Rev. Hiram Bingham. The missionaries were instrumental in introducing Western education, medicine, and technology to the kingdom. They also helped to spread Christianity throughout the islands, and Lahaina became a major center of missionary activity.

### Whaling

In the mid-19th century, Lahaina became a major port for the whaling industry. Whalers from around the world came to Lahaina to refuel, repair their ships, and restock their supplies. The whaling industry brought wealth and prosperity to the town, but it also led to the exploitation of Hawaii's natural resources and the decline of the native population.

### Kamehameha III

In 1820, Kamehameha III moved the capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii from Lahaina to Honolulu, and Lahaina began to decline in importance. However, the town remained a major center of commerce and culture, and Kamehameha III continued to visit and support the town throughout his reign.

### 20th century

In the 20th century, Lahaina experienced a renewed surge of growth and development. The town became a popular tourist destination, and many historic sites were restored and preserved. In 1962, the Lahaina Historic Trail was established, which features many of the town's historic sites and landmarks.

## 2023 wildfire

On August 8, 2023, a devastating wildfire broke out in the Lahaina area, forcing the evacuation of thousands of residents and tourists. The fire burned for several days, destroying hundreds of homes and businesses and causing widespread damage to the town's infrastructure. The fire was eventually brought under control, but not before it had caused an estimated $1 billion in damages and displaced thousands of people.

# Geography

Lahaina is located on the west coast of Maui, approximately 20 miles northwest of the city of Wailuku. The town is situated in a fertile valley surrounded by the West Maui Mountains, which rise to an elevation of over 5,000 feet. The climate is tropical, with average temperatures ranging from 70 to 85 degrees Fahrenheit throughout the year.

## Climate

Lahaina has a tropical savanna climate, with two distinct seasons: a dry season from April to October and a wet season from November to March. The average annual rainfall is around 30 inches, with most of the rain falling during the wet season. The town is also susceptible to hurricanes and tropical storms, which can bring heavy rain and strong winds.

# Demographics

As of the 2020 census, the population of Lahaina was approximately 12,000 people. The town has a diverse population, with a mix of Native Hawaiians, Caucasians, Asians, and other ethnic groups. The median age is around 40 years old, and the median household income is around $60,000.

# Arts and culture

Lahaina is known for its rich cultural heritage and vibrant arts scene. The town is home to many museums, galleries, and performance venues, including the Lahaina Heritage Museum, the Wo Hing Temple Museum, and the Maui Arts & Cultural Center. The town also hosts several festivals and events throughout the year, including the Lahaina Festival, the Maui Film Festival, and the Hawaii Food and Wine Festival.

# Sports

Lahaina is home to several sports teams, including the Lahaina Warriors high school football team and the Maui Heat basketball team. The town also has several parks and recreational facilities, including the Lahaina Civic Center, the Lahaina Recreation Center, and the Ka'anapali Beach Park.

# Popular culture

Lahaina has been featured in several movies and television shows, including the popular TV series "Hawaii Five-0" and the movie "50 First Dates". The town has also been the subject of several books and songs, including the novel "From Here to Eternity" by James Jones and the song "Lahaina" by the Hawaiian musician Don Ho.

2023 Mutua Madrid Open – Women's singles

The 2023 Mutua Madrid Open – Women's singles was the women's singles tennis event of the 2023 Mutua Madrid Open, a WTA 1000 tournament. It was played on outdoor clay courts at the Park Manzanares in Madrid, Spain, from April 25 to May 6, 2023.

# Seeds

The top eight seeds received a bye into the second round. 

1.  Iga Świątek (Champion)
2.  Aryna Sabalenka (Third Round)
3.  Jessica Pegula (Quarterfinals)

### Section 3

Coco Gauff received a bye into the second round. In the second round, Gauff defeated Kaia Kanepi, 6–3, 6–1. In the third round, Gauff defeated Mirra Andreeva, 6–3, 6–2. In the fourth round, Gauff defeated Veronika Kudermetova, 6–2, 7–5.

### Section 4

## Bottom half

Aryna Sabalenka received a bye into the second round. In the second round, Sabalenka defeated Irina-Camelia Begu, 6–4, 6–1. In the third round, Sabalenka lost to Mirra Andreeva, 6–3, 0–6, 6–3.

### Section 6

### Section 7

Maria Sakkari received a bye into the second round. In the second round, Sakkari defeated Shelby Rogers, 6–4, 6–1. In the third round, Sakkari lost to Iga Świątek, 6–1, 6–1.

### Section 8

Ekaterina Alexandrova lost to Xinyu Wang in the first round, 6–2, 6–3. In the second round, Wang lost to Ons Jabeur, 6–2, 6–1. In the third round, Jabeur defeated Daria Kasatkina, 6–1, 6–2.

article:
Tornado outbreak of March 21–23, 2022

A significant tornado outbreak occurred across the Southern United States on March 21–23, 2022, affecting multiple states and causing widespread damage and loss of life. The outbreak was characterized by a complex weather pattern that led to the development of numerous tornadoes, including several long-lived and intense ones.

# Meteorological synopsis

## March 21

A strong low-pressure system developed over the Rocky Mountains on March 20, 2022, and began to move eastward across the Great Plains. As it interacted with a stationary front over the Southern United States, a complex weather pattern emerged, featuring a mix of instability, wind shear, and moisture. This setup was conducive to the development of thunderstorms, some of which would eventually produce tornadoes.

## March 22

As the low-pressure system continued to move eastward, the stationary front became more active, leading to the development of a strong cold front that swept across the Southern United States. This front interacted with the warm, moist air from the Gulf of Mexico, creating a highly unstable atmosphere that was ripe for tornadoes. The Storm Prediction Center (SPC) issued a Moderate Risk (4/5) for severe thunderstorms and tornadoes across several states, including Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia.

## March 23

The cold front continued to move eastward, but its interaction with the warm air from the Gulf of Mexico remained strong, leading to the persistence of a highly unstable atmosphere. The SPC maintained a Moderate Risk (4/5) for severe thunderstorms and tornadoes across several states, including North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee. As the day progressed, the outbreak began to wind down, but not before several more tornadoes touched down.

# Confirmed tornadoes

## March 21 event

A total of 15 tornadoes were confirmed to have touched down on March 21, 2022, across several states, including Texas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF2 that occurred in Texas, causing significant damage to homes and businesses.

## March 22 event

A total of 35 tornadoes were confirmed to have touched down on March 22, 2022, across several states, including Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF3 that occurred in Louisiana, causing widespread destruction and loss of life.

## March 23 event

A total of 10 tornadoes were confirmed to have touched down on March 23, 2022, across several states, including North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF2 that occurred in North Carolina, causing significant damage to homes and businesses.

## Gretna–Arabi–New Orleans East, Louisiana

One of the most significant tornadoes of the outbreak occurred in Louisiana, where an EF3 tornado touched down in the Gretna-Arabi area and moved northeastward through New Orleans East. The tornado caused widespread destruction, including homes and businesses, and resulted in several fatalities.

# Non-tornadic effects

In addition to the tornadoes, the outbreak also produced significant non-tornadic effects, including large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rainfall. Several states experienced severe thunderstorms that caused widespread damage and disruption.

# Preparations and impacts

The outbreak had significant impacts on several states, including Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia. Emergency management officials issued warnings and advisories, and several schools and businesses were closed as a precaution. The American Red Cross and other disaster relief organizations were deployed to affected areas to provide assistance.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the outbreak saw widespread damage and disruption, with several states declaring states of emergency. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) was deployed to affected areas to provide assistance, and several non-profit organizations provided aid to affected communities.

* Severe weather in the United States

2022 Women's Cricket World Cup

The 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup was the twelfth edition of the Women's Cricket World Cup, which was held in New Zealand from 4 March to 3 April 2022. The tournament featured eight teams and was won by Australia, who defeated England in the final.

#Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup began in 2017 and involved a series of tournaments and matches played over several years. The top four teams from the 2017 Women's Cricket World Cup, plus the top two teams from the 2017-2020 ICC Women's Championship, qualified directly for the tournament. The remaining two teams were determined through a qualifying tournament, which was held in Zimbabwe in November 2021.

The teams that qualified for the tournament were:

* Australia
* England
* India
* New Zealand
* Pakistan
* South Africa
* West Indies
* Bangladesh

#Venues

The 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup was held at six venues across New Zealand:

* Bay Oval, Mount Maunganui
* Eden Park, Auckland
* Hagley Oval, Christchurch
* Seddon Park, Hamilton
* University Oval, Dunedin
* Basin Reserve, Wellington

#Squads

Each team was required to submit a squad of 15 players for the tournament. The squads were:

* Australia: Meg Lanning (c), Rachael Haynes, Alyssa Healy, Beth Mooney, Tahlia McGrath, Ellyse Perry, Ash Gardner, Jess Jonassen, Alana King, Megan Schutt, Darcie Brown, Nicola Carey, Annabel Sutherland, Georgia Wareham, Amanda-Jade Wellington

* New Zealand: Amy Satterthwaite (c), Suzie Bates, Sophie Devine, Lauren Down, Maddy Green, Brooke Halliday, Hayley Jensen, Fran Jonas, Jess Kerr, Melie Kerr, Katey Martin, Hannah Rowe, Lea Tahuhu, Amy Wakeman, Eden Carson
* Pakistan: Bismah Maroof (c), Aiman Anwer, Aliya Riaz, Anam Amin, Diana Baig, Fatima Sana, Ghulam Fatima, Iram Javed, Javeria Khan, Muneeba Ali, Nahida Khan, Nida Dar, Omaima Sohail, Sidra Amin, Sidra Nawaz
* South Africa: Suné Luus (c), Anneke Bosch, Trisha Chetty, Nadine de Klerk, Mignon du Preez, Lara Goodall, Shabnim Ismail, Sinalo Jafta, Marizanne Kapp, Ayabonga Khaka, Masabata Klaas, Lizelle Lee, Nonkululeko Mlaba, Tumi Sekhukhune, Chloe Tryon
* West Indies: Stafanie Taylor (c), Aaliyah Alleyne, Shemaine Campbelle, Shamilia Connell, Deandra Dottin, Afy Fletcher, Cherry-Ann Fraser, Chinelle Henry, Kycia Knight, Hayley Matthews, Chedean Nation, Karishma Ramharack, Shakera Selman, Rashada Williams, Anisa Mohammed
* Bangladesh: Nigar Sultana (c), Rumana Ahmed, Sharmin Akhter, Nahida Akter, Jahanara Alam, Suraiya Azmin, Fargana Hoque, Fahima Khatun, Murshida Khatun, Salma Khatun, Khadija Tul Kubra, Sanjida Islam, Shamima Sultana, Lata Mondal, Ritu Moni

#Match officials

The match officials for the tournament were:

* Umpires: Ahmed Shah Pakteen, Alex Wharf, Asif Yaqoob, Chris Gaffaney, Gregory Brathwaite, Jacqueline Williams, Kim Cotton, Langton Rusere, Lauren Agenbag, Sue Redfern, Wayne Knights
* Match referees: Daniel Belsham, Gary Baxter, Garry Timms, Graham Lloyd, Steve Bernard

#Matches

A total of 31 matches were played during the tournament, including the final.

#Warm-up matches

Each team played two warm-up matches before the start of the tournament. The warm-up matches were:

* Australia vs. New Zealand, 27 February, Bay Oval, Mount Maunganui
* England vs. South Africa, 27 February, University Oval, Dunedin
* India vs. West Indies, 27 February, Seddon Park, Hamilton
* Pakistan vs. Bangladesh, 27 February, Basin Reserve, Wellington
* Australia vs. England, 28 February, Bay Oval, Mount Maunganui
* New Zealand vs. South Africa, 28 February, University Oval, Dunedin
* India vs. Pakistan, 28 February, Seddon Park, Hamilton

#Group stage

The group stage consisted of seven rounds, with each team playing each other team once.

##Round 1

article:
Piolets d'Or

The Piolets d'Or is an annual award in the field of mountaineering and alpinism, considered the "Oscars of mountaineering". It was created in 1991 by the French climbing magazine Montagnes and the Groupe de Haute Montagne (GHM), a French mountaineering club. The award aims to recognize and celebrate outstanding achievements in the world of mountaineering, acknowledging the most impressive and innovative ascents of the year.

# History

The Piolets d'Or was first awarded in 1992, with the inaugural ceremony taking place in Chamonix, France. The award quickly gained international recognition and has since become one of the most prestigious honors in the mountaineering community. Over the years, the Piolets d'Or has undergone changes in its format, criteria, and voting process, but its core mission remains the same: to celebrate the spirit of adventure, exploration, and excellence in mountaineering.

## Multiple winners

Several individuals have won the Piolets d'Or multiple times, demonstrating their consistent excellence and dedication to the sport. Notable multiple winners include:

* Reinhold Messner (Italy), who won the award a record four times
* Lynn Hill (USA), who won the award three times
* Ueli Steck (Switzerland), who won the award twice

# Criteria

The Piolets d'Or award is given to recognize outstanding achievements in mountaineering, taking into account factors such as:

* The difficulty and novelty of the ascent
* The style and purity of the climb
* The commitment and dedication required
* The impact on the mountaineering community

A jury composed of experienced mountaineers, climbers, and journalists reviews nominations and selects the winners. The voting process is confidential, and the winners are announced at an annual ceremony.

# Reception

The Piolets d'Or has been widely acclaimed and respected within the mountaineering community. The award is seen as a symbol of excellence and a celebration of the sport's values. However, the award has also faced criticism and controversy over the years.

## Criticism

Some have criticized the Piolets d'Or for:

* Fostering competition and elitism within the mountaineering community
* Overemphasizing difficulty and risk-taking, potentially encouraging reckless behavior
* Ignoring or downplaying the achievements of lesser-known or amateur climbers

Despite these criticisms, the Piolets d'Or remains one of the most prestigious and respected awards in the world of mountaineering.

article:
Attempted Assassination of Imran Khan

The attempted assassination of Imran Khan, the 22nd Prime Minister of Pakistan, occurred on November 3, 2022, in Wazirabad, Punjab, Pakistan. The incident took place during the 2022 Azadi March-II, a protest march led by Khan against the government of Shehbaz Sharif. The assassination attempt left Khan wounded and sparked widespread condemnation and protests across the country.

# Background

## Ousting of Imran Khan

Imran Khan was ousted as Prime Minister of Pakistan on April 10, 2022, through a no-confidence vote in the National Assembly. The vote was held after a coalition of opposition parties, led by the Pakistan Muslim League (N) (PML-N) and the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP), submitted a no-confidence motion against Khan's government. The motion was passed with 174 votes in favor, two more than the required majority.

Khan's ouster led to widespread protests and demonstrations across the country, with his supporters accusing the opposition parties of conspiring against him. Khan himself claimed that the United States was involved in a conspiracy to remove him from power, a claim that was denied by the US State Department.

## 2022 Azadi March-II

In response to his ouster, Khan announced the 2022 Azadi March-II, a protest march from Lahore to Islamabad to demand new elections and the resignation of the Sharif government. The march began on October 28, 2022, and was expected to culminate in a massive rally in Islamabad on November 4, 2022.

The march was seen as a test of Khan's popularity and a challenge to the Sharif government, which had been facing criticism for its handling of the economy and other issues. The government had banned the march, citing security concerns, but Khan's supporters had vowed to press on.

# Shooting

On November 3, 2022, as Khan's convoy was passing through Wazirabad, Punjab, a gunman opened fire on the vehicles. Khan was hit in the leg and was rushed to a hospital in Lahore for treatment. Several others were also injured in the shooting.

The attack was widely condemned, with many calling it an attempt to silence Khan and undermine his movement. Khan's supporters accused the government of being behind the attack, while the government denied any involvement.

# Suspects

The police arrested several suspects in connection with the shooting, including a man named Faisal Butt, who was identified as the main suspect. Butt was reportedly a supporter of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), Khan's party, but had been expelled from the party for disciplinary reasons.

The police said that Butt had confessed to the crime, claiming that he had acted alone and was motivated by a desire for revenge against Khan. However, Khan's supporters and many others raised questions about the official narrative, pointing to inconsistencies in the police account and suggesting that the attack may have been more complex and involved more people.

# Reactions

## Domestic

The attempted assassination of Imran Khan sparked widespread outrage and condemnation across Pakistan. Khan's supporters took to the streets, protesting against the government and demanding justice for their leader. The protests were largely peaceful, but there were reports of clashes between protesters and police in some areas.

Many Pakistani politicians and public figures condemned the attack, including Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, who described it as a "heinous act of terrorism." The Pakistan Army also issued a statement, condemning the attack and expressing its support for Khan's right to peaceful protest.

However, some opposition politicians and commentators suggested that Khan was to blame for the attack, accusing him of creating a culture of violence and intolerance. Khan's supporters rejected these claims, pointing to his long record of advocating for non-violent protest and peaceful change.

## International

The attempted assassination of Imran Khan also drew international attention and condemnation. The United States, the European Union, and other countries issued statements condemning the attack and expressing support for Khan's right to peaceful protest.

The international community also expressed concern about the implications of the attack for Pakistan's democracy and stability. Many observers noted that the attack had highlighted the deep divisions and tensions within Pakistani society, and warned that the country was at risk of further violence and instability.

* Assassination attempts

article:
Banat of Craiova

The Banat of Craiova was a historical and administrative division of the Habsburg Monarchy that existed from 1718 to 1739, located in what is now western Romania. It was one of the two Banats that made up the Habsburgs' territorial gains in the region, the other being the Banat of Temeschwar.

# History

## Austrian conquest

In 1718, the Habsburgs, led by Prince Eugene of Savoy, defeated the Ottoman Empire in the Austro-Turkish War of 1716-1718, gaining control of a significant portion of the Balkans. The Treaty of Passarowitz, signed on July 21, 1718, marked the beginning of Habsburg rule in the region. The Banat of Craiova was established as a military border province, with its capital in the city of Craiova.

## Government creation

The Habsburgs created a new administrative system in the Banat of Craiova, modeled after the military border system used in other parts of the empire. The province was divided into districts, each governed by a military commander. The government was responsible for maintaining order, collecting taxes, and providing defense against Ottoman attacks. The Habsburgs also encouraged the settlement of colonists from other parts of the empire, including Germans, Hungarians, and Serbs.

## Boyar and peasant resistance

The establishment of the Banat of Craiova was met with resistance from the local boyar class, who had traditionally held power in the region. The boyars saw the Habsburgs as foreign occupiers and resented the imposition of a new administrative system. Peasants also resisted the new government, which imposed heavy taxes and forced labor. In 1720, a rebellion broke out in the Banat, led by a group of boyars and peasants. The rebellion was eventually put down, but it marked the beginning of a long period of tension between the Habsburgs and the local population.

## Austrian consolidation

Despite the initial resistance, the Habsburgs were able to consolidate their power in the Banat of Craiova over the next several decades. They invested in infrastructure, including roads, bridges, and canals, and encouraged the development of trade and commerce. The province became an important center for the production of grain, livestock, and textiles. The Habsburgs also established a system of education and healthcare, which helped to improve living standards in the region.

## Ottoman reconquest

In 1737, the Ottoman Empire, led by Sultan Mahmud I, launched a series of attacks on the Habsburgs' territorial gains in the Balkans. The Banat of Craiova was one of the first provinces to fall, and by 1739, the entire region was back under Ottoman control. The Habsburgs were forced to cede the Banat of Craiova, along with other territories, in the Treaty of Belgrade, signed on September 18, 1739.

# Legacy

## "Colonial" precedent

The Banat of Craiova was an important precedent for the Habsburgs' later colonial endeavors. The experience of governing a diverse population in a distant region helped to shape the Habsburgs' approach to colonial administration. The use of a military border system, the encouragement of colonization, and the investment in infrastructure were all strategies that would be employed in later colonial ventures.

## Cultural survivals

Despite the relatively short period of Habsburg rule in the Banat of Craiova, the region retained a number of cultural and architectural legacies from the period. Many of the buildings constructed during the Habsburg period, including churches, monasteries, and public buildings, still stand today. The region also retained a number of cultural traditions, including folk music and dance, which were influenced by the Habsburgs' cultural policies.

# Symbols

The Banat of Craiova had its own coat of arms, which featured a shield with a red and gold checkerboard pattern, surmounted by a crown. The coat of arms was used on official documents, coins, and other symbols of the province.

# Notes

The Banat of Craiova was an important chapter in the history of the Habsburg Monarchy, marking the beginning of the empire's expansion into the Balkans. Despite its relatively short existence, the province left a lasting legacy in the region, shaping the course of cultural, economic, and political development for centuries to come.

article:
FIDE Grand Prix 2022

The FIDE Grand Prix 2022 was a series of three chess tournaments that took place from February to April 2022. The tournaments were part of the World Chess Championship cycle, with the top two players qualifying for the Candidates Tournament 2022.

# Organization

The FIDE Grand Prix 2022 was organized by the World Chess Federation (FIDE) and sponsored by PhosAgro. The tournaments were held in Berlin, Germany, and Belgrade, Serbia. The events were played under the classical time control, with a total prize fund of €280,000 for each tournament.

# Players

Twenty-four players participated in the FIDE Grand Prix 2022, including several top-ranked grandmasters. The players were selected based on their FIDE ratings, as well as their performance in previous tournaments. The participants included:

* World Chess Championship candidate and former challenger, Sergey Karjakin
* Former World Chess Champion, Viswanathan Anand
* Top-ranked grandmasters, Wesley So, Levon Aronian, and Shakhriyar Mamedyarov
* Rising stars, Andrey Esipenko, Parham Maghsoodloo, and Vincent Keymer

# Format

The FIDE Grand Prix 2022 consisted of three tournaments, each featuring a round-robin stage followed by a knockout stage.

## Time controls and tie-breaks

The round-robin stage was played under the classical time control, with each player having 90 minutes for the first 40 moves, followed by 30 minutes for the rest of the game, with an increment of 30 seconds per move. In the event of a tie, the players would compete in a rapid playoff, with a time control of 15 minutes for each player, plus a 10-second increment per move.

## Grand Prix points

The players earned Grand Prix points based on their performance in each tournament. The winner of each tournament earned 13 points, with the runner-up earning 10 points, and the third-place finisher earning 7 points. The remaining players earned points based on their finish in the tournament.

## Prize money

The total prize fund for each tournament was €280,000, with the winner earning €20,000, the runner-up earning €15,000, and the third-place finisher earning €10,000.

# Tournament 1 - Berlin, Germany

article:
2022 Malaysian General Election

The 2022 Malaysian general election was the 15th general election in Malaysia, held on November 19, 2022, to elect members of the Dewan Rakyat, the lower house of the Parliament of Malaysia. The election saw a significant shift in the country's political landscape, with the opposition alliance, Pakatan Harapan, winning the most seats but falling short of a majority.

#Background

##Previous election

The 2018 Malaysian general election saw the opposition alliance, Pakatan Harapan, led by Mahathir Mohamad, win a majority of seats in the Dewan Rakyat, ending the 61-year rule of the Barisan Nasional coalition. However, the Pakatan Harapan government was short-lived, as it collapsed in February 2020 due to internal conflicts.

Since the 2018 election, Malaysia has experienced a series of significant events that have shaped the country's politics. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a major impact on the economy and public health, and the government's response to the crisis has been a major issue in the election campaign.

##2020–22 political crisis

The 2020–22 political crisis in Malaysia began in February 2020, when the Pakatan Harapan government collapsed due to internal conflicts. The crisis saw the formation of a new government led by Muhyiddin Yassin, who was appointed as the Prime Minister by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong. However, the new government was short-lived, as it collapsed in August 2021 due to a loss of confidence in the Prime Minister.

#Electoral system

Malaysia uses a first-past-the-post electoral system, where the candidate with the most votes in each constituency wins the seat. The country is divided into 222 constituencies, each electing one member to the Dewan Rakyat.

#Timeline

##Dissolution of parliament

The 14th Parliament of Malaysia was dissolved on October 10, 2022, by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong, on the advice of the Prime Minister, Ismail Sabri Yaakob.

##Extra-parliamentary parties

##Nominated candidates

A total of 1,355 candidates were nominated for the election, with the opposition alliance, Pakatan Harapan, fielding candidates in all 222 constituencies.

#Campaign

##Timing of election

The election was held on November 19, 2022, with polling stations opening at 8am and closing at 5pm.

##Youth vote

The youth vote was a major issue in the election campaign, with the opposition alliance, Pakatan Harapan, targeting young voters with its manifesto promises.

2021 SEA Games

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games, officially known as the 31st Southeast Asian Games, was a multi-sport event held in Hanoi, Vietnam from May 12 to May 23, 2022. The games were originally scheduled to take place in 2021, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the event was postponed to 2022.

# Host selection

The bidding process for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games began in 2012, with several cities expressing interest in hosting the event.

## Hanoi

Hanoi, the capital city of Vietnam, was one of the first cities to express interest in hosting the games. The city had previously hosted several major international events, including the 2003 Southeast Asian Games.

## Ho Chi Minh City

Ho Chi Minh City, the largest city in Vietnam, also bid to host the games. The city had a strong track record of hosting major events, including the 2007 Asian Indoor Games.

## Decision

In November 2012, the Southeast Asian Games Federation (SEAGF) announced that Hanoi would host the 2021 Southeast Asian Games. The decision was made after a thorough evaluation of the bids from both Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.

# Postponement

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the 2021 Southeast Asian Games were postponed to 2022. The decision was made by the SEAGF in July 2021, after consultations with the Vietnamese government and other stakeholders.

# Preparation

Preparations for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games began in earnest after the postponement was announced. The Vietnamese government and the SEAGF worked closely together to ensure that the event would be a success.

The total budget for the 2021 Southeast Asian Games was estimated to be around $69 million. The budget was allocated for various purposes, including venue construction, athlete accommodations, and marketing.

2022 Nepalese local elections

The 2022 Nepalese local elections were held on May 13, 2022, to elect representatives to local government bodies in Nepal. The elections were a significant milestone in the country's democratic process, marking the second time that local elections were held since the promulgation of the new constitution in 2015.

Electoral system

The 2022 Nepalese local elections followed a mixed electoral system, which combines elements of both first-past-the-post (FPTP) and proportional representation (PR) systems. In the FPTP system, voters elected representatives to local government bodies, including mayors, deputy mayors, and ward chairs, through a simple majority vote. In the PR system, voters elected representatives to local assemblies, including provincial and federal legislatures, through a proportional representation system.

Qualification for candidates

To be eligible to contest the elections, candidates had to meet certain qualifications, including being a citizen of Nepal, being at least 25 years old, and having a minimum educational qualification of grade 10. Candidates also had to be a resident of the electoral area and had to have a good moral character.

Exit poll
###Mayor/Chairperson post

According to exit polls conducted by various organizations, including the Kantipur Media Group and the Nepal Magazine, the Nepali Congress was expected to win the majority of mayor and chairperson posts in urban areas, while the Communist Party of Nepal (UML) was expected to perform well in rural areas.

Results

The results of the 2022 Nepalese local elections were announced on May 18, 2022, five days after the polls were held. The results showed that the Nepali Congress had emerged as the largest party, winning 315 mayoral and chairperson posts, followed by the CPN (UML), which won 255 posts.

Incidents
